tit.e: Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan)
Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan)
Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan)

sen.j: 清和源氏（せいわげんじ）は、56代清和天皇の皇子を祖とする賜姓皇族。
sen.e: Seiwa-Genji is shisei kozoku (member of the Imperial Family conferred with a family name) whose ancestor is the prince of the 56th Emperor Seiwa.
Seiwa-Genji was shisei kozoku (member of the Imperial Family conferred with a family name) whose ancestor is the prince of the 56th Emperor Seiwa.
Seiwa-Genji was a shisei kozoku (member of the Imperial Family conferred a family name) whose ancestor was the prince of the fifty-sixth Emperor, Seiwa.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 清和源氏とは
sen.e: Seiwa-Genji is:
Seiwa-Genji was:
Seiwa-Genji was:

sen.j: 清和源氏は清和天皇を祖とする皇胤が源姓を賜り成立した一族。
sen.e: Seiwa-Genji is a family of Imperial descendants of Emperor Seiwa, given the family name of Minamoto.
Seiwa-Genji was a family of Imperial descendants of Emperor Seiwa, given the family name of Minamoto.
Seiwa-Genji was a family of Imperial descendants of Emperor Seiwa, who were given the family name, Minamoto.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 源頼朝以来、武家政権の主催者の血族として栄えてきた。
sen.e: After MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, Seiwa-Genji flourished as organizers' blood relatives of the samurai government.
After MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, Seiwa-Genji flourished as organizers' blood relatives of the samurai government.
Since MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, Seiwa-Genji flourished as the blood relatives of the organizers of the samurai government.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: もっとも栄えたのは第六皇子貞純親王の子の源経基の子孫の系統。
sen.e: The line of descendents of MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, the son of the sixth Prince Sadazumi, was the most prosperous.
The line of descendents of MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, the son of the sixth Prince Sadazumi, was the most prosperous.
Since MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, Seiwa-Genji flourished as the blood relatives of the organizers of the samurai government.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 中級貴族であった経基の子源満仲（多田満仲）が藤原北家による摂関政治の確立に協力して中央における武門としての地位を築き、摂津国川辺郡多田の地に武士団を形成する。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka (TADA no Manju), the son of Tsunemoto who was a middle-ranking noble, cooperated with the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan for the establishment of regency, thereby gaining the status as the samurai family in the center and formed a samurai group in Tada, Kawabe District, Settsu Province.

MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka (TADA no Manju), the son of Tsunemoto who was a middle-ranking noble, cooperated with the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan for the establishment of regency, thereby gaining the status as the central samurai family formed a samurai group in Tada, Kawabe District, Settsu Province.

MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka (TADA no Manju), the son of Tsunemoto who was a middle-ranking noble, cooperated with the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan for the establishment of Sekkanseiji (regency), thereby gaining the status as the central samurai family and forming a samurai group in Tada, Kawabe District, Settsu Province.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: そして、彼の子である源頼光、源頼親、源頼信らも父と同様に摂関家に仕え武門としての勢力を拡大した。
sen.e: His sons, MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, MINAMOTO no Yorichika, MINAMOTO no Yorinobu, etc., also served sekkan-ke (line of regents and advisers) like his father and expanded the power as the samurai family.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: His sons, MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, MINAMOTO no Yorichika, MINAMOTO no Yorinobu, etc., also served sekkan-ke (line of regents and advisers) like his father and expanded power under the samurai family.

His sons, MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, MINAMOTO no Yorichika, MINAMOTO no Yorinobu, etc., like his father, also served the sekkan-ke (the families which produced the Regent and the Chief Adviser to the Emperor) and expanded their power as samurai family.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 後に主流となった頼信の嫡流が東国の武士団を支配下に置いて武家の棟梁としての地位を固め、源頼朝の代に鎌倉幕府を開き武家政権を確立した。
sen.e: The direct descendant of Yorinobu, who later became mainstream, solidified his position as the head of the samurai family with the eastern samurai groups under control and MINAMOTO no Yoritomo began Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to establish the samurai government.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The direct descendant of Yorinobu, who later became mainstream, solidified his position as the head of the samurai family with the eastern samurai groups under control, and it was then that MINAMOTO no Yoritomo began Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to establish the samurai government.

The direct descendants of Yorinobu, who later became the mainstream, solidified their position as the head of the samurai family with the eastern samurai groups under their control, and in the era of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, they founded the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and established the samurai government.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 清和源氏を称している近世大名の多くは、その事実が歴史学的に証明されたわけではない。
sen.e: Most of daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) in early-modern times who call themselves Seiwa-Genji have not been historically proven to be true.
Most daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) in early-modern times who called themselves Seiwa-Genji have not been historically proven to be true.
Most daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) in early-modern times who called themselves Seiwa-Genji are not historically proven to be so.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: ちなみに武家の棟梁である征夷大将軍には清和源氏の者しかなれないという説がある。
sen.e: According to one theory, only a person from Seiwa-Genji can be seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), the head of the samurai family.
According to one theory, only a person from Seiwa-Genji can be seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), the head of the samurai family.
According to one theory, only Seiwa-Genji could become seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), the head of the samurai family.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、坂上田村麻呂や大伴弟麻呂や藤原頼経といった先例が存在した。
sen.e: However, there are precedents for seii taishogun, such as SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro, OTOMO no Otomaro, and FUJIWARA no Yoritsune.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, there are precedents for seii taishogun, such as SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro, OTOMO no Otomaro, and FUJIWARA no Yoritsune.
However, there were seii taishogun such as SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro, OTOMO no Otomaro, and FUJIWARA no Yoritsune in the past.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また、織田信長も征夷大将軍に就任する可能性があった（三職推任問題）。
sen.e: Further, Nobunaga ODA could be appointed as seii taishogun (Sanshoku suinin mondai (the question of the three alternative positions)).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Further, Nobunaga ODA could could have been appointed as seii taishogun (Sanshoku suinin mondai (the question of the three alternative positions)).
Furthermore, Nobunaga ODA could have been appointed as seii taishogun (Sanshoku suinin mondai (historical event regarding the Oda government)).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: そのため、現在ではこの説は俗説とされている。
sen.e: Therefore, this theory is now regarded as a common saying.
Therefore, this theory is now regarded as a common saying.
Therefore, this theory is now regarded as a myth.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

tit.j: 清和源氏の起源と変遷
tit.e: Origin and transition of Seiwa-Genji
Origin and transition of Seiwa-Genji
Origin and transition of Seiwa-Genji

sen.j: 清和源氏の起源は、清和天皇の第六皇子貞純親王の子である源経基が臣籍降下により源姓を賜ったことに遡る。
sen.e: The origin of Seiwa-Genji is that MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, the son of the sixth Prince Sadazumi of Emperor Seiwa, was given the family name of Minamoto in demotion from nobility to subject.
The origin of Seiwa-Genji is that MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, the son of the sixth Prince Sadazumi of Emperor Seiwa, was given the family name of Minamoto in demotion from nobility to subject.
The origin of Seiwa-Genji is that MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, the son of the sixth Prince Sadazumi of Emperor Seiwa, was given the family name of Minamoto in demotion from nobility to subject.

sen.j: 源経基の名跡を継いだ源満仲は、摂津国川辺郡多田（現・兵庫県川西市多田）を本拠地として源氏武士団を形成した。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, who succeeded the family name after MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, formed the Genji samurai group based in Tada, Kawabe District, Settsu Province (present-day Tada, Kawanishi City, Hyogo Prefecture).

MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, who succeeded the family name after MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, formed the Genji samurai group based in Tada, Kawabe District, Settsu Province (present-day Tada, Kawanishi City, Hyogo Prefecture).

MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, who succeeded the family name after MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, formed the Genji samurai group based in Tada, Kawabe District, Settsu Province (present-day Tada, Kawanishi City, Hyogo Prefecture).

sen.j: 酒呑童子退治などで有名な満仲の長男の源頼光も、摂津国に拠点を置いたことから摂津源氏と呼ばれる。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, the eldest son of Mitsunaka, famous for the dispose of Shuten Doji (the leader of a group of bandits that roamed the region around Kyoto), is also called Settsu-Genji (Minamoto clan) as he was based in Settsu Province.

MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, the eldest son of Mitsunaka, famous for the dispose of Shuten Doji (the leader of a group of bandits that roamed the region around Kyoto), is also called Settsu-Genji (Minamoto clan) as he was based in Settsu Province.

MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, the eldest son of Mitsunaka, famous for the extermination of Shuten Doji (the leader of a group of bandits that roamed the region around Kyoto), was also called Settsu-Genji (Minamoto clan) as he was based in Settsu Province.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 摂津源氏の中で多田に土着する系統を多田源氏といい、傍流からは美濃に土着した美濃源氏が輩出される。
sen.e: Among the Settsu-Genji, the family line native to Tada is called Tada-Genji (Minamoto clan), and from the branch line native to Mino, Mino-Genji (Minamoto clan) was produced.
Among the Settsu-Genji, the family line native to Tada is called Tada-Genji (Minamoto clan), and from the branch line native to Mino, sprung Mino-Genji (Minamoto clan).
Among the Settsu-Genji, the family line native to Tada was called Tada-Genji (Minamoto clan), and from the branch line native to Mino, sprung Mino-Genji (Minamoto clan).

sen.j: 満仲の次男の源頼親の系統は、大和国宇野（現・奈良県）を本拠地としたことから大和源氏といわれる。
sen.e: The family line of MINAMOTO no Yorichika, Mitsunaka's second son, is called Yamato-Genji (Minamoto clan) as it was based in Uno, Yamato Province (present-day Nara Prefecture).
The family line of MINAMOTO no Yorichika, Mitsunaka's second son, is called Yamato-Genji (Minamoto clan) as it was based in Uno, Yamato Province (present-day Nara Prefecture).
The family lineage of MINAMOTO no Yorichika, the second son of Mitsunaka, was called Yamato-Genji as it was based in Uno, Yamato Province (present-day Nara Prefecture).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また、満仲の三男の源頼信の系統（厳密に言えば、源義忠・源義時流）は、河内国壷井(現・大阪府羽曳野市壷井)を本拠としたことから河内源氏といわれる
sen.e: Further, the family line of MINAMOTO no Yorinobu, Mitsunaka's third son, (more precisely, the line of MINAMOTO no Yoshitada and Minamoto no Yoshitoki) is called Kawachi-Genji (Minamoto clan) as it was based in Tsuboi, Kawachi Province (present-day Tsuboi, Habikino City, Osaka Prefecture).

Further, the family line of MINAMOTO no Yorinobu, Mitsunaka's third son, (more precisely, the line of MINAMOTO no Yoshitada and Minamoto no Yoshitoki) is called Kawachi-Genji (Minamoto clan) as it was based in Tsuboi, Kawachi Province (present-day Tsuboi, Habikino City, Osaka Prefecture).

Additionally, the family lineage of MINAMOTO no Yorinobu, the third son of Mitsunaka, (more precisely, the line of MINAMOTO no Yoshitada and MINAMOTO no Yoshitoki) was called Kawachi-Genji as it was based in Tsuboi, Kawachi Province (present-day Tsuboi, Habikino City, Osaka Prefecture).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 頼信の子、源頼義は前九年の役にて陸奥国奥六郡に蛮拠する俘囚長 安倍氏 (奥州)を討ち、その子、源義家は出羽の俘囚長、清原氏の内紛を治め（後三年の役）、声望を高めた。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi, the son of Yorinobu, defeated Abe clan (Oshu), the head of barbarians thrived in Okuroku District, Mutsu Province in Zen Kunen no Eki (Former Nine Years' Campaign), and his son MINAMOTO no Yoshiie suppressed the internal discord for Kiyohara clan, the head of barbarians thrived in Dewa (Gosannen no Eki (Later Three Years' War)), thereby increasing the reputation.

MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi, the son of Yorinobu, defeated Abe clan (Oshu), the head of barbarians thrived in Okuroku District, Mutsu Province in Zen Kunen no Eki (Former Nine Years' Campaign), and his son MINAMOTO no Yoshiie suppressed the internal discord for Kiyohara clan, the head of barbarians thrived in Dewa (Gosannen no Eki (Later Three Years' War)), thereby increasing the reputation.

MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi, the child of Yorinobu, defeated Abe clan (Oshu), the head of barbarians who thrived in Okuroku District, Mutsu Province in Zen Kunen no Eki (the Early Nine Years' War), and his child, MINAMOTO no Yoshiie, suppressed the internal discord of Kiyohara clan, the head of barbarians who thrived in Dewa (Gosannen no Eki (the Later Three Years' War)), thereby increasing his reputation.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 河内源氏が東国に足掛かりを持つようになったのもこの頃である。
sen.e: At this time, Kawachi-Genji began to establish a toehold in the east.
At this time, Kawachi-Genji began to establish a toehold in the east.
At this time, Kawachi-Genji began to establish a toehold in the east.

sen.j: 河内源氏はこのように武名を現したことから、事実上清和源氏の嫡流の地位を占めるに至った。
sen.e: Kawachi-Genji won samurai name accordingly, thereby substantially establishing the position of the direct descendant of Seiwa-Genji.
Kawachi-Genji won his samurai name accordingly, thereby substantially establishing the position of the direct descendant of Seiwa-Genji.
Thus, Kawachi-Genji won their samurai name, and practically established their position as the direct descendant of Seiwa-Genji.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: このような河内源氏の興隆は、時の権力者 白河法皇の警戒を招く。
sen.e: Such prosperity of Kawachi-Genji led to the vigilance of Cloistered Emperor Shirakawa, the powers that be.
Such prosperity of Kawachi-Genji led to the vigilance of Cloistered Emperor Shirakawa, the powers that be.
Such prosperity of Kawachi-Genji alarmed the Cloistered Emperor Shirakawa, who was in power at the time.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 義家の長男・源義親は対馬国守に任ぜられ、その後義親は反朝廷的行為などの罪を問われて追討を受けている。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoshichika, the eldest son of Yoshiie, was appointed as Tsushima-kokushu （the Lord of Tsushima Province), but later expelled by being accused of anticourt behaviors.
MINAMOTO no Yoshichika, the eldest son of Yoshiie, was appointed as Tsushima-kokushu （the Lord of Tsushima Province), but later expelled after being accused of anticourt behaviors.
MINAMOTO no Yoshichika, the eldest son of Yoshiie, was appointed as Tsushima-kokushu （the Lord of Tsushima Province), but later expelled after being accused of anticourt behaviors.

sen.j: 義家の死後、家督を継いだ源義忠が源義光の策謀で暗殺されると河内源氏の勢力は弱体化する。
sen.e: After the Yoshiie's death, MINAMOTO no Yoshitada, who succeeded the reign of the family, was assassinated by machinations of MINAMOTO no Yoshimitsu, which led to the weakening of the power of Kawachi-Genji.

After Yoshiie's death, MINAMOTO no Yoshitada, who succeeded the reign of the family, was assassinated by machinations of MINAMOTO no Yoshimitsu, which led to the weakening of the power of Kawachi-Genji.

After Yoshiie's death, MINAMOTO no Yoshitada, who succeeded the reign of the family, was assassinated by machinations of MINAMOTO no Yoshimitsu, which led to the weakening of the power of Kawachi-Genji.

sen.j: 源義忠の後を継いだ源為義が効果的な施策を打ち出せずにいた一方、白河院の寵愛を受けた伊勢平氏傍流の平正盛が地位を固めていった。
sen.e: While MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi who succeeded MINAMOTO no Yoshitada was unable to implement effective measures, TAIRA no Masamori, a branch of Ise-Heishi (Taira clan) who won the Retired Emperor Shirakawa's favor, solidified his position.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: While MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi who succeeded MINAMOTO no Yoshitada was unable to implement effective measures, TAIRA no Masamori, a branch of Ise-Heishi (Taira clan) who won the Retired Emperor Shirakawa's favor, solidified his position.

While MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi, who succeeded MINAMOTO no Yoshitada, was unable to implement effective measures, TAIRA no Masamori, a branch of Ise-Heishi (Taira clan) who won the favor of Retired Emperor Shirakawa, solidified his position.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: このことで、武門の中で河内源氏の勢力は相対的に低下していった。
sen.e: Accordingly, the relative power of Kawachi-Genji in the samurai family declined.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Accordingly, the relative power of Kawachi-Genji in the samurai family declined.
Accordingly, the relative power of Kawachi-Genji in the samurai family declined.

sen.j: 不遇を囲った源為義の子で東国に下っていた源義朝は、保元の乱において、河内源氏恩顧の関東の武士を糾合して天皇方に立った。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo who was in the east, the son of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi who lived in adverse circumstances, gathered together samurai in Kanto region who received Kawachi-Genji's kind favors thereby to support the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo who was in the east, the son of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi who lived in adverse circumstances, gathered together samurai in the Kanto region who received Kawachi-Genji's kind favors thereby to support the Emperor.

MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo, who lived in the east and was the son of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi, who lived in unfortunate circumstances, gathered samurai from the Kanto region who received Kawachi-Genji's special favors, and supported the Emperor in the Hogen Disturbance.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: そして上皇方の父為義や源為朝など弟を敵に回して勝利した。
sen.e: As a result, he won a victory, making an enemy on his father Tameyoshi and younger brother MINAMOTO no Tametomo who supported the Retired Emperor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As a result, he won a victory, making an enemy of his father Tameyoshi and younger brother MINAMOTO no Tametomo who supported the Retired Emperor.
He won a victory, turning against his father Tameyoshi and younger brother MINAMOTO no Tametomo who supported the Retired Emperor.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、一族の多くを失った源義朝は、同じく天皇方についた平清盛と比較して勢力を伸ばすことができなかった。
sen.e: However, MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo lost many of his family and could not expand his power compared to TAIRA no Kiyomori who was also supported the Emperor.
However, MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo lost many of his family and could not expand his power compared to TAIRA no Kiyomori who also supported the Emperor.
However, MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo, who lost many of his family, could not expand his power compared to TAIRA no Kiyomori, who also supported the Emperor.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: そのため、義朝は河内源氏の勢力回復をはかり、藤原信頼と手を結んで後白河天皇を幽閉、平治の乱を起こす。
sen.e: Accordingly, Yoshitomo attempted to recover the power of Kawachi-Genji and dealt with FUJIWARA no Nobuyori to confine Emperor Goshirakawa and began the Heiji War.
Accordingly, Yoshitomo attempted to recover the power of Kawachi-Genji and dealt with FUJIWARA no Nobuyori to confine Emperor Goshirakawa and began the Heiji War.
Accordingly, Yoshitomo, in an attempt to recover the power of Kawachi-Genji, formed an alliance with FUJIWARA no Nobuyori to confine Emperor Goshirakawa and began the Heiji War.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 一時天下を我が物にした義朝だったが、平清盛らが秘密裏に上皇らを救出したことで形勢逆転。
sen.e: Although Yoshitomo temporarily took the reins of government, the situation was reversed by TAIRA no Kiyomori who secretly rescued the Retired Emperor and others.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Although Yoshitomo temporarily took the reins of government, the situation was reversed by TAIRA no Kiyomori who secretly rescued the Retired Emperor and others.
Although Yoshitomo once took the reins of government, the tide turned when TAIRA no Kiyomori secretly rescued the Retired Emperor, etc.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 義朝は敗退して平安京を落ち、東国へ向かう。
sen.e: Yoshitomoto was defeated and exiled to the east from Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Yoshitomoto was defeated and exiled to the east from Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto).
Yoshitomoto was defeated and exiled to the east from Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto).

sen.j: しかし、道中で、腹心の鎌田政清の舅になる尾張国の長田忠致の手にかかって殺害された。
sen.e: Along the way, however, he was killed by Tadamune OSADA from Owari Province, his confident Masakiyo KAMATA's father-in-law.
Along the way, however, he was killed by Tadamune OSADA from Owari Province, his confident Masakiyo KAMATA's father-in-law.
However, he was killed along the way by Tadamune OSADA from Owari Province, who was the father-in-law of his trustworthy assistant, Masakiyo KAMATA.

sen.j: 20年余の時を経て、以仁王の令旨を奉じた摂津源氏の源頼政、熊野に潜んでいた河内源氏庶流の源行家らの檄を受け、河内源氏の源義朝の子である源頼朝、源希義、源範頼、源義円、源義経ら兄弟や、源義朝の弟の源義賢の子であり、頼朝の従兄弟にあたる源義仲（木曾次郎義仲）、八幡太郎義家の弟の源義光（新羅三郎義光）の子孫の甲斐源氏武田氏の武田信義らが各地で挙兵し、俗に源平合戦と呼ばれる治承・寿永の乱が発生する。
sen.e: After over 20 years, with exhortations by Settsu-Genji MINAMOTO no Yorimasa who obeyed Prince Mochihito's order and a Kawachi-Genji branch MINAMOTO no Yukiie who had lain in Kumano, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, MINAMOTO no Mareyoshi, MINAMOTO no Noriyori, MINAMOTO no Gien, and MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune (siblings, the sons of Kawachi-Genji MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo); MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka (Jiro Yoshinaka KISO), the son of MINAMOTO no Yoshikata (a brother of MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo) and a cousin of Yoritomo; Nobuyoshi TAKEDA from Kai-Genji (Minamoto clan) Takeda clan, a descendant of MINAMOTO no Yoshimitsu (Shinra-Saburo MINAMOTO-no-Yoshimitsu) (a brother of Yoshiie HACHIMAN TARO); and others raised armies across the country to begin the Jisho-Juei War (the so-called Genpei War).

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府において、源氏一門は、血統や功績等により源姓を称することが許される御門葉と、源姓を称することが適わず、名字を称するものに区別された。
sen.e: In Kamakura bakufu, the Minamoto family was divided into two types: gomonyo (a family with a honorary status) who were allowed to call one's family name Minamoto for their blood line or achievements; and families with other family names as it was not permitted to call themselves Minamoto.

sen.e: Takauji ASHIKAGA, the head of the distinguished Ashikaga clan from Seiwa-Genji who stood head above the others during the confusion in the end of Kamakura bakufu, destroyed counterforce and was appointed as seii taishogun as the head of the samurai family to establish Muromachi bakufu in 1338.

tit.e: Yozei-Genji (Minamoto clan) Theory
Yozei-Genji (Minamoto clan) Theory
Yozei-Genji (Minamoto clan) Theory

sen.j: 陽成源氏説は明治の歴史学者星野恒の説で、『清和源氏の祖は実は清和天皇ではなく陽成天皇であるが、暴君であったとされる陽成帝の名を冠せず清和源氏を名乗った』というものである。
sen.e: The Yozei-Genji Theory was stated by the historian Hisashi HOSHINO in the Meiji period: "The ancestor of Seiwa-Genji was in fact Emperor Yozei, not Emperor Seiwa; but as Emperor Yozei was a tyrant, the name 'Seiwa' was prefixed instead of 'Yozei' to call Seiwa-Genji."

The Yozei-Genji Theory was stated by the historian Hisashi HOSHINO in the Meiji period as follows: "The ancestor of Seiwa-Genji was in fact Emperor Yozei, not Emperor Seiwa; but as Emperor Yozei was a tyrant, the name 'Seiwa' was prefixed instead of 'Yozei' to call Seiwa-Genji."

The Yozei-Genji Theory by historian Hisashi HOSHINO in the Meiji period claimed, "The ancestor of Seiwa-Genji was actually Emperor Yozei, not Emperor Seiwa; but as Emperor Yozei was a tyrant, the name Seiwa-Genji was used instead Yozei-tei."
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 石清水八幡宮祠官田中家文書の中に源頼信が誉田山陵（応神天皇陵）に納めたと称する永承元年告文に「先人新発、其先経基、其先元平親王、其先陽成天皇、其先清和天皇」と明記してあることが根拠である。
sen.e: This is supported by the family document of Tanaka who was a Shinto priest of Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine, describing that the Imperial instruction of 1046, which was dedicated to Homutarama no misasagi (Mausoleum of Emperor Ojin) by MINAMOTO no Yorinobu, explicitly describes that: "the ancestors are Shinbochi, Tsunemoto, Imperial Prince Motohira, Emperor Yozei, and Emperor Seiwa in the order of generation from newest to oldest."

sen.j: （赤坂恒明氏） 『権記』に引用されている天暦七年の王氏爵不正事件に現れる、清和天皇の子孫でありながら陽成天皇子孫を詐称したとして罰せられた源経忠を経基あるいはその兄弟と推定し、頼信が願文で陽成天皇の子孫であることは真実であると主張して名誉回復を図ったと解釈する。
sen.e: (Tsuneaki AKASAKA) Assuming that MINAMOTO no Tsunetada, whose name appeared in Oujinojaku fusei jiken (the case of unauthorized use of the family name O) of 953 cited in "Gonki" (FUJIWARA no Yukinari's diary) and was charged in representing himself as the descendant of Emperor Yozei (he was actually the descendant of Emperor Seiwa), is Tsunemoto or his brother, it is interpreted that Yorinobu attempted to retrieve his honor by insisting in a petition that he was in fact the descendant of Emperor Yozei.

sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 平安期には経基流以外の人物も史料上にみえている。
sen.e: In the Heian period, a person other than Tsunemoto also appears in historical sources.

sen.j: 滋野氏…源姓ではないが、清和天皇の第5皇子貞保親王の後裔とも称する。
sen.e: Shigeno clan…Shigeno clan is not the family name of Minamoto, but is called the descendant of Imperial Prince Sadayasu, the fifth prince of Emperor Seiwa.
Shigeno clan…Shigeno clan is not the family name of Minamoto, but is called the descendant of Imperial Prince Sadayasu, the fifth prince of Emperor Seiwa.

tit.j: 清和源氏の後裔と称される一族
tit.e: Family called the descendant of Seiwa-Genji
Family called the descendant of Seiwa-Genji
Family called the descendant of Seiwa-Genji

sen.j: 三河国の豪族松平氏は、松平信光の代には賀茂氏を名乗っていたという。
sen.e: The Matsudaira clan, the local ruling family in Mikawa Province, called themselves the Kamo clan in the generation of Nobumitsu MATSUDAIRA.
The Matsudaira clan, the local ruling family in Mikawa Province, called themselves the Kamo clan during the generation of Nobumitsu MATSUDAIRA.
The Matsudaira clan, the local ruling family in Mikawa Province, called themselves the Kamo clan during the generation of Nobumitsu MATSUDAIRA.

sen.j: 徳川家康が徳川氏に改姓するにあたって称した氏は藤原氏であった。
sen.e: When Ieyasu TOKUGAWA adopted Tokugawa as his family name, he represented himself Fujiwara clan.
When Ieyasu TOKUGAWA adopted Tokugawa as his family name, he represented himself as part of the Fujiwara clan.
When Ieyasu TOKUGAWA adopted Tokugawa as his family name, he represented himself as part of the Fujiwara clan.

sen.j: そのため、慣例で源氏がなるとされていた征夷大将軍に任官されるために、新田氏の末裔となるべく系図を借り受けて「源朝臣」を称するようになったという解釈がされることが多い。
sen.e: It is often interpreted that, as seii taishogun was appointed from the Minamoto clan by convention, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA borrowed the family tree so as to be a descendant of Nitta clan, thereby calling himself "Minamoto no Ason"so that he could become the seii taishogun.

It is often interpreted that, as seii taishogun was appointed from the Minamoto clan by convention, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA borrowed the family tree so as to be a descendant of Nitta clan, thereby calling himself "Minamoto no Ason"so that he could become the seii taishogun.

It is often viewed that, as seii taishogun was appointed from the Minamoto clan by convention, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA borrowed a spot in the family tree so as to be a descendant of the Nitta clan, thereby calling himself 'Minamoto no Ason' so that he could become seii taishogun.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、笠谷和比古等の研究によると、1588年の後陽成天皇聚楽第行幸の際には、家康はすでに源朝臣を名乗っていたという。
sen.e: According to the study by Kazuhiko KASAYA et al., however, Ieyasu already called himself Minamoto no Ason in the Emperor Goyozei's Imperial visit to Jurakudai (Hideyoshi's residence and office in Kyoto) of 1588.

According to the study by Kazuhiko KASAYA et al., however, Ieyasu already called himself Minamoto no Ason in the Emperor Goyozei's Imperial visit to Jurakudai (Hideyoshi's residence and office in Kyoto) of 1588.

According to the study by Kazuhiko KASAYA et al., however, Ieyasu already called himself Minamoto no Ason in the Emperor Goyozei's Imperial visit to Jurakudai (Hideyoshi's residence and office in Kyoto) of 1588.

sen.j: また、家康の祖父の松平清康の代には既に世良田氏の子孫を名乗っていたという説もある。
sen.e: There is another theory that as early as in the generation of Kiyoyasu MATSUDAIRA, the grandfather of Ieyasu, Ieyasu called himself the descendant of Serada clan.
There is another theory that as early as in the generation of Kiyoyasu MATSUDAIRA, the grandfather of Ieyasu, Ieyasu had referred to himself as a descendant of the Serada clan.
Another theory claims that by the era Kiyoyasu MATSUDAIRA, the grandfather of Ieyasu, Ieyasu had already referred to himself as a descendant of the Serada clan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: いずれにしても、徳川氏は清和源氏を仮冒したとされる。
sen.e: In either case, the Tokugawa clan gave themselves out as Seiwa-Genji.
In either case, the Tokugawa clan gave themselves out as Seiwa-Genji.
In either case, the Tokugawa clan is believed to have deceptively used the name, Seiwa-Genji.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: その後家康は慶長八年（1603年）に征夷大将軍と源氏長者に任じられ、幕府を開いた。
sen.e: Later in 1603, Ieyasu was appointed as seii taishogun and Genji choja to establish the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
Later in 1603, Ieyasu was appointed as seii taishogun and Genji choja to establish the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
Later, in 1603, Ieyasu was appointed as seii taishogun and Genji choja, and established the bakufu.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 薩摩国の大名（鎌倉時代は守護、室町時代は守護大名、戦国時代は戦国大名、江戸時代は薩摩藩主）島津氏も元来は惟宗氏の出で、島津家の祖・島津忠久は惟宗広言とされてきた（近年では惟宗忠康の子という説が有力）。
sen.e: The Shimazu clan, a feudal lord in Satsuma Province (which was called Shugo (provincial constable) in the Kamakura period, Shugo daimyo (Japanese territorial lord as provincial constable) in the Muromachi period, Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period, and the lord of Satsuma domain in the Edo period), was also originally from Koremune clan, and Tadahisa SHIMAZU, the ancestor of Shimazu family, was assumed to be KOREMUNE no Hirokoto (the recent widely-accepted theory is that Tadahisa SHIMAZU was a child of KOREMUNE no Tadayasu).

The Shimazu clan, a feudal lord in Satsuma Province (which was called Shugo (provincial constable) in the Kamakura period, Shugo daimyo (Japanese territorial lord as provincial constable) in the Muromachi period, Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period, and the lord of Satsuma domain in the Edo period), was also originally from Koremune clan, and Tadahisa SHIMAZU, the ancestor of Shimazu family, was assumed to be KOREMUNE no Hirokoto (the recent widely-accepted theory is that Tadahisa SHIMAZU was a child of KOREMUNE no Tadayasu).

The Shimazu clan, a daimyo (feudal lord) (which were called Shugo (provincial constable) in the Kamakura period, Shugo daimyo (Shugo that became daimyo) in the Muromachi period, Sengoku daimyo (daimyo in the Sengoku period) in the Sengoku period, and the lord of Satsuma domain in the Edo period) in Satsuma Province, was also originally from Koremune clan, and Tadahisa SHIMAZU, the founder of Shimazu family, was referred to as KOREMUNE no Hirokoto (the recent widely-accepted theory is that Tadahisa SHIMAZU was a child of KOREMUNE no Tadayasu).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: だが忠久が源頼朝により抜擢・厚遇された。
sen.e: Tadahisa was selected and kindly treated by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Tadahisa was selected and kindly treated by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo.
However, Tadahisa was selected and received cordial treatment by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: その理由付けとして「忠久は頼朝の庶子」という系図を借り受けて「源朝臣」を称するようになったとされている。
sen.e: Supposedly, the reason was that Tadahisa came to call himself "Minamoto no Ason" borrowing the family tree: "Tadahisa was Yoritomo's child born out of wedlock."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Supposedly, the reason was that Tadahisa came to call himself "Minamoto no Ason" borrowing the family tree: "Tadahisa was Yoritomo's child born out of wedlock."
It is believed that Tadahisa referred to himself as 'Minamoto no Ason' by borrowing a spot in the family tree showing that 'Tadahisa was Yoritomo's child born out of wedlock.'
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 故に島津氏も徳川氏同様清和源氏を仮冒したとされる。
sen.e: Accordingly, the Shimazu clan also gave themselves out as Seiwa-Genji, as the Tokugawa clan.
Accordingly, the Shimazu clan also gave themselves out as Seiwa-Genji, as the Tokugawa clan.
Accordingly, like the Tokugawa clan, the Shimazu clan also deceptively used the name, Seiwa-Genji.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 島津氏（源頼朝の落胤を祖と称した）
sen.e: Shimazu clan (called an illegitimate child of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo the ancestor)
Shimazu clan (called an illegitimate child of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo the ancestor)
Shimazu clan (claimed that their ancestor was an illegitimate child of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo)
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 徳川氏（新田氏の一族と称した）
sen.e: Tokugawa clan (called themselves a family of Nitta clan)
Tokugawa clan (called themselves a family of Nitta clan)
Tokugawa clan (called themselves a member of Nitta clan)
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 舜天王統（王朝の祖、舜天が源為朝であるという伝説がある）
sen.e: Shinten royal line (There is a legend that Shuten, the ancestor of the dynasty, was MINAMOTO no Tametomo.)
Shinten royal line (There is a legend that Shuten, the ancestor of the dynasty, was MINAMOTO no Tametomo.)
